questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of decreased vision in his left eye following a recent blunt trauma to the face during a sporting event. Upon examination, you observe a ring-shaped pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule of his left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
A 3-yr old child presents with Right Convergent Squint of 6 month's duration. What is appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe glasses and defer surgery until the child is 5 yrs old

options.label: D
options.text: Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of gradual blurring of vision over the past year. Upon examination, you notice a distortion of the corneal reflex at the center of the cornea, along with thinning of the cornea in the center. There is evidence of Munson's sign. Which of the following findings would you expect in the refractive error of this patient?

A 54-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided visual field loss. Upon examination, his left pupil constricts briskly when a bright light is shown into his left eye, but his right pupil does not constrict when light is shown into his right eye. Which structure lesion would lead to Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary response?
A 35-year-old male on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:

A 14-year-old obese girl presents with a headache. She states that the headache has been on and off for weeks and has a moderate intensity. She also states that she has had intermittent loss of vision for seconds at a time for the last two to three days. Physical examination reveals the above image. A noncontrast head CT scan is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Lumbar puncture with opening pressure
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Lumbar puncture with opening pressure

questions.text: True about telecanthus is:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

options.label: B
options.text: Widely separated medial wall of orbits

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intercanthal distance with increased interpupillary distance

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

questions.text: The test given below in the image is:

A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive vision loss and night blindness. Upon examination, the patient displays characteristic retinal degeneration with peripheral bone spicule pigmentation. Which of the following syndromes is NOT likely associated with this clinical presentation?

A 45-year-old patient presents with severe eye pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in their right eye. They have a history of Herpes Zoster infection on the same side of their face a few weeks ago. On examination, you notice decreased visual acuity and inflammation in the eye. Which of the following complications of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus is the patient most unlikely experiencing?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of decreased vision and pain in his left eye. He reports a history of trauma to his right eye one week ago due to a workplace accident involving a metallic object. On examination, his right eye shows signs of recent trauma with corneal perforation. However, upon examination of the left eye, there are signs of severe inflammation, including uveitis and vitritis. The intraocular pressure is elevated, and there are no signs of trauma or infection in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis for the left eye?
Give the diagnosis, from the clinical photograph given below?

options.label: A
options.text: Cotton wool spots in the retina

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with a 15-year history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the ophthalmology clinic with visual disturbances. On fundoscopic examination, you observe multiple hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and hard exudates in both eyes. However, one eye has a presentation more than the other. There is a lesion near the macula with vascularization and fluid accumulation, causing severe visual impairment. The patient reports no recent trauma. Which of the following findings is atypical for diabetic retinopathy in this case?
What is incorrect about this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Consist of head, neck, and body

options.label: B
options.text: Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.correct_answer: B. Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.text: Which antiglaucoma medication should be cautiously prescribed to a patient who operates heavy machinery due to its potential to cause drowsiness?
The action of superior rectus is:
Which of the following is the most important factor in the prevention of the endophthalmitis in cataract surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: One-week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine

questions.text: When managing a patient with elevated intraocular pressure uncontrolled by medication, which of the following would be ideal candidate for Argon laser trabeculoplasty?
Economic blindness is defined when visual acuity falls below:
Steroids are contraindicated in:
Identify the condition:
A value of 0.75D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was?

A male patient with a history of hyper mature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:

A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?

A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe pain and swelling around his left eye after a recent accident while playing sports. Upon further inquiry, he reveals that he was struck directly on the eye with a fast-moving object. Considering the mechanism of injury described, which of the following is not typically associated with blowout fractures?
A 17-year-old girl with myopia started using her elder sister’s contact lenses. This sharing of contact lens may lead to the spread of which of the following infections?
What is the most common cause for the appearance shown in the image below?
The ophthalmic surgical instrument shown in the figure is used in which of the following conditions?

A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shown in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shown in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
The Fovea centralis is responsible for the visual acuity of a person. How much is it’s diameter?
The only extraocular muscle which does not arise from the apex of the orbit is:

A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with complaints of blurry vision after cataract surgery. Fundus fluorescein angiography reveals a characteristic 'flower petals' appearance in the macula region? What is he MOST likely suffering from?

A 39-year-old woman presents with complains of a six-month history of amenorrhea, galactorrhoea and an increasingly severe frontal headache. On further questioning she has had several near misses while driving recently but denies any visual problems. She has no past medical or surgical history and takes no regular medicines. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband and works as a teacher. She is happy in her work and not stressed. Neurological examination reveals a visual field defect but is otherwise normal. Given the likely diagnosis, which visual field defect is expected?

A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3 days history of discharge, pain, and redness in his left eye. He states that his ophthalmologist surgically placed a "filter" in this eye 5 years ago to control his glaucoma. Visual acuity is 20/200 in this eye. Inspection reveals a very injected and swollen eye. You also note a very milky layer of fluid accumulating in the anterior chamber as shown in image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing "spots" floating around in her right eye. Today, she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a "shadow" in her peripheral vision that moves when looking up and down. Her medical history is significant for migraine headaches; however, she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
The finding that all three types of Duane’s syndrome share is:

A 42-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision and distortion in her left eye for the past few months. Upon further examination, you notice a bulging area in the posterior pole of the left eye, along with thinning of the sclera. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) confirms the presence of posterior staphyloma. Visual acuity in the left eye is 20/80. Intraocular pressure is within normal limits, and there are no signs of retinal detachment or other complications. In which of the following conditions the given scenario is seen in:
Identify the field defect:
For transplantation cornea is preserved in:
Neonatal conjunctivitis is caused by all except:
Which is not a clinical feature of right sided VIth nerve palsy:

A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
Most common cause of blindness in children is:
In concomitant squint:
In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates between:

options.label: A
options.text: Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer.

options.label: B
options.text: Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve fiber layer and rest of retina.

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressively worsening vision in both eyes over the past year. He describes his vision as cloudy, and he has difficulty seeing at night and reading small print. On examination, his visual acuity is 20/100 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral lens opacities consistent with cataracts. His intraocular pressures are normal, and there are no other significant findings on ocular examination. Given this patient's clinical presentation and examination findings, which of the following will provide earliest visual rehabilitation:

options.label: B
options.text: Intracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

options.label: C
options.text: Extracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.text: A 20-year-old female of thin stature, presented to the OPD with redness, irritation and watering in both eyes for the past 1 month. She had a history of loss of appetite & weight. Examination showed a pinkish white nodule with ulcerated apex at the limbus. What would be the investigation of choice?
Ptosis in Horner's syndrome, is due to paralysis of:
3 months old infant with watering, lacrimal sac on pressing causes regurgitation of mucopus material. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.label: D
options.text: Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back. Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
